matched.matchReason: The expected finding and actual finding both describe the same critical vulnerability: JWT tokens with 'alg':'none' being accepted without signature verification. The actual finding provides more detailed evidence showing legitimate tokens and forged admin tokens are both accepted, allowing authentication bypass and privilege escalation. This directly matches the expected vulnerability of unsigned JWT token manipulation.

extra.title: Missing CSRF Token Protection on Login Form
extra.assessment: New discovery - This is a legitimate security vulnerability not covered in the expected findings. The login endpoint accepts cross-origin POST requests without CSRF token validation, allowing potential account takeover via malicious websites.

extra.title: Missing Rate Limiting on Login Endpoint - Brute Force Attack Possible
extra.assessment: New discovery - This is a legitimate security vulnerability not covered in the expected findings. The login endpoint has no rate limiting, allowing unlimited brute force attempts against user accounts.

extra.title: Vertical Privilege Escalation via JWT Token Forgery
extra.assessment: Related to matched finding - While the expected finding covers JWT manipulation, this actual finding specifically documents vertical privilege escalation where authenticated users can modify JWT role claims to become administrators. This is a specific exploitation scenario of the unsigned JWT vulnerability.

extra.title: Horizontal Privilege Escalation - Other User Account Access via JWT Forgery
extra.assessment: Related to matched finding - This documents horizontal privilege escalation where users can forge tokens to impersonate other users. This is another specific exploitation scenario enabled by the unsigned JWT vulnerability.

extra.title: Missing JWT Token Expiration - Indefinite Session Duration
extra.assessment: New discovery - JWT tokens lack expiration claims (exp) and server-side expiration validation, allowing tokens to remain valid indefinitely. This is a separate but related JWT security issue not covered in expected findings.

extra.title: Missing Security Flags on JWT Authentication Cookie
extra.assessment: New discovery - JWT authentication cookies lack HttpOnly, Secure, and SameSite flags, making them vulnerable to XSS theft, MITM interception, and CSRF attacks. This is a separate cookie security configuration issue.

extra.title: Weak Password Policy - Default/Weak Credentials (user:user) Accepted
extra.assessment: New discovery - The application accepts trivially weak credentials (user:user) indicating no password policy enforcement. This is a separate authentication weakness not covered in expected findings.

extra.title: Information Disclosure - Server Version in HTTP Headers
extra.assessment: New discovery - Application exposes Werkzeug 3.0.3 and Python 3.13.3 versions in Server header, enabling reconnaissance and vulnerability research.

extra.title: Missing Security HTTP Headers
extra.assessment: New discovery - Application is missing critical security headers (X-Content-Type-Options, X-Frame-Options, CSP, HSTS, etc.), leaving it vulnerable to content sniffing, clickjacking, and other header-based attacks.
